questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue. She also reports generalized itchiness that started approximately 2 months ago. Two weeks ago, she noticed yellowing of her eyes. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She uses eyedrops for persistent dryness of the eyes. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are generalized skin excoriations. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7700/mm3



Platelet count
332,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
122 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin

3.1 mg/dL


 Direct bilirubin

2.5 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase

452 U/L


 AST
155 U/L


 ALT
168 U/L


 Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


 Hepatitis B core IgM antibody
negative


 Hepatitis B surface antibody
positive


 Hepatitis C antibody
negative


Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows mildly increased echogenicity of the liver. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of the inferior vena cava would result in Budd-Chiari syndrome, which manifests with fatigue, hepatomegaly, elevated liver transaminase enzymes, and increased levels of conjugated bilirubin due to intrahepatic cholestasis. However, unconjugated bilirubin levels would also be increased due to hepatocellular damage (i.e., mixed hyperbilirubinemia), the liver would be tender, and patients would have other clinical features such as pedal edema, ascites, and/or acute renal failure.

B) CORRECT:

In primary biliary cholangitis, dramatic hypercholesterolemia (often > 1000 mg/dL) can occur due to impaired biliary elimination of cholesterol. Hypercholesterolemia results in the development of cutaneous xanthomas and xanthelasma. Further workup in suspected PBC includes measuring serum antibodies (antimitochondrial antibodies, antinuclear antibodies), MRI, and liver biopsy in ambiguous cases.

In addition to sicca syndrome, conditions that are associated with PBC include autoimmune thyroiditis (e.g., Graves disease, Hashimoto thyroiditis), CREST syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis.

See "Differential diagnoses of cholestatic biliary disease" table.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonic ulceration is seen in patients with ulcerative colitis (UC), which is often associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC can manifest with fatigue, hepatomegaly, elevated AST/ALT, and cholestatic jaundice. However, ultrasonography in PSC would show thickening of the bile duct wall and PSC is more common in men between 30–40 years of age. Although cases of concomitant UC and PBC have rarely been reported, another finding is far more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Butterfly vertebrae are found in patients with Alagille syndrome, which causes fatigue, elevated liver transaminases, and features of cholestatic jaundice. However, Alagille syndrome is a severe genetic disorder with onset of symptoms at the latest during infancy. Patients also have other associated congenital anomalies, e.g., cardiac defects, eye deformities, a short stature, and/or a dysmorphic facies, none of which is present in this patient. Since survival of patients typically depends on a liver transplant, it is unlikely for a patient to reach adulthood without diagnosis and treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased CA 19-9 levels would be seen in patients with pancreatic carcinoma, which can cause fatigue, cholestatic jaundice, and hepatomegaly (due to hepatic metastases). However, cholestatic jaundice in patients with pancreatic cancer would be associated with dilation of the biliary ducts, pancreatic duct, and/or gall bladder on ultrasonography. In addition, hepatic metastases would appear as hypoechoic lesions on ultrasonography. Moreover, patients with metastatic pancreatic carcinoma would typically have a history of weight loss and/or anorexia. Symptoms of sicca syndrome (e.g., dry eyes), however, would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal artery microaneurysms are seen in patients with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which can occur with both acute and chronic hepatitis B infection. Hepatitis B infection can cause fatigue, hepatomegaly, elevated liver transaminase enzymes, and increased levels of conjugated bilirubin due to intrahepatic cholestasis. However, unconjugated bilirubin levels would also be increased due to hepatocellular damage (i.e., mixed hyperbilirubinemia). Furthermore, positive anti-HBs alongside negative anti-HBc and HbsAg indicate immunity to hepatitis B after vaccination. Moreover, patients with PAN would have other clinical features such as fever, abdominal pain, arthralgia, and/or cutaneous manifestations of vasculitis (e.g., palpable purpura, livedo reticularis).

G) INCORRECT:

Kayser-Fleischer rings are most commonly seen in patients with Wilson disease who have not received chelation therapy. Wilson disease can cause fatigue, hepatomegaly, elevated liver transaminase enzymes, and increased levels of conjugated bilirubin (due to intrahepatic cholestasis). However, symptom onset typically occurs during adolescence. Furthermore, unconjugated bilirubin levels would also be increased due to hepatocellular damage (i.e., mixed hyperbilirubinemia), and patients are unlikely to survive beyond the age of 40 years without therapy (e.g., chelation, transplantation). Rarely, Kayser-Fleischer rings are found in other chronic cholestatic conditions, including PBC, but another finding is much more likely.
questions.hint: In a middle-aged woman, features of cholestatic jaundice (conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, ↑ alkaline phosphatase, unexplained itching), fatigue, hepatomegaly, and hepatocellular damage (↑ ALT, ↑ AST), along with symptoms of sicca syndrome (e.g., dry eyes, dry mouth) are highly suggestive of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for his annual health maintenance examination. The patient feels well. He has a history of hypertension, for which he currently takes lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks five to six beers on weekends. He is 181 cm tall (5 ft 11 in) and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:


Total cholesterol
263 mg/dL


High-density lipoprotein cholesterol
36 mg/dL


Triglycerides
180 mg/dL


In addition to dietary and lifestyle modification, administration of which of the following agents is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B3 (niacin) has mild LDL-lowering effects and is not recommended as a first-line drug for patients with high LDL-C levels. Niacin can be used in the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor, is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that is reserved for patients who do not tolerate the first-line drug or have contraindications for it. It may also be administered to augment the effect of the first-line drug if it does not sufficiently lower LDL levels.

C) INCORRECT:

PCSK9 inhibitors such as alirocumab and evolocumab are effective in lowering LDL levels. They are used as second-line lipid-lowering agents and can be considered if treatment goals are not met with first-line therapy.

D) CORRECT:

HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors, more commonly referred to as statins, are the first-line treatment for dyslipidemia. According to the 2018 AHA/ACC guidelines, adults with an LDL-cholesterol concentration ≥ 190 mg/dL should be started on statin therapy. Statins are the most effective drug for reducing LDL levels and also improving HDL and triglyceride levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Bile acid resins such as cholestyramine can be used as an adjunct to first-line therapy but are not recommended as monotherapy for dyslipidemia. Bile acid resins only minimally lower LDL, and the gastrointestinal side effects (nausea, bloating, cramping) and increase in liver enzymes often necessitate discontinuation of treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

PPARα activators, which are more commonly referred to as fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate), are most commonly used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. They are not recommended as LDL-lowering agents. Another lipid-lowering agent with a more potent effect on LDL levels is preferred at this point.
questions.hint: To calculate LDL, use the following equation: LDL (mg/dL) = total cholesterol - HDL - (triglycerides/5), where “triglycerides/5” represents VLDL. In this patient, LDL = 263 mg/dL - 36 mg/dL - (180 mg/dL/5) = 191 mg/dL. Given this patient's age, history of hypertension, and LDL level, he is at elevated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of seizures controlled with levetiracetam. She has needed glasses for the past 13 years. Her father died of pancreatic cancer. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the face is shown. This patient is most likely at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas are tumors that are particularly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, which often manifests initially with impaired eyesight and might also present with seizures. Although disease onset may not occur until adulthood, the lesions on the eyelids of this patient do not resemble the characteristic skin lesions found in neurofibromatosis type 1 (café au lait spots, Lisch nodules).
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma is a skin cancer associated with sun exposure, advanced age, and precancerous lesions such as leukoplakia or actinic keratosis. While leukoplakia most commonly presents as a persistent white plaque in the oral cavity, actinic keratoses are erythematous lesions with a sandpaper-like texture that affect sun-exposed skin. The xanthelasmas seen in this patient are not associated with the development of cSCC.
Image Description:

Left temporal and cheek region of a 75-year-old female patient with long-term exposure to UV radiation: All three skin lesions are erythematous. There is an atropic crater in the upper lesion. Yellow-brown, squamous changes can be seen in the lower two lesions. This dermatological findings, in association with the patient's history of long-term UV radiation exposure, most likely indicates actinic keratosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastric cancer is often asymptomatic until advanced disease stages present with abdominal pain, hematemesis, or gastric outlet obstruction. A further symptom that may occur is malignant acanthosis nigricans, which presents with verrucous skin lesions predominantly on the axillae, groin, or neck. While gastric cancer cannot be ruled out conclusively in an asymptomatic patient without further workup, the xanthelasmas seen in this patient suggest a diagnosis that increases her risk for a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Early-onset glaucoma is a condition that is often associated with congenital diseases such as Sturge-Weber syndrome. While patients may present with seizures and initially only require glasses to correct refractive errors associated with glaucoma, the diagnosis is usually established in childhood. This patient's skin lesions also do not resemble the characteristic port-wine stain seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with xanthelasmas, small nodular lipid deposits that manifest bilaterally on the upper eyelids. Xanthelasmas are a symptom of underlying lipid disorders (e.g., familial hypercholesterolemia, obesity), which increase the risk for atherosclerosis and associated cardiovascular diseases such as coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and stroke. The next best step in management would be to identify the underlying cause of this patient's lipid disorder via laboratory analysis of serum lipid levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor associated with tuberous sclerosis. While the condition can manifest with seizures and skin lesions that affect the face (adenoma sebaceum), it is not associated with xanthelasmas and is unlikely in the absence of further characteristic symptoms (e.g., intellectual disability, brain tumors, ash-leaf spots).
questions.hint: This patient has bilateral xanthelasma (sharply demarcated, yellow plaques) on the nasal aspect of her eyelids.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because they are worried about her weight. They have repeatedly tried to make her lose weight over the past year by encouraging her to exercise and eat healthy without any success. She feels well, and her medical history is unremarkable. Her father has hypercholesterolemia and coronary artery disease and her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She is 164 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 83 kg (183 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 127/81 mm Hg. She is at the > 90th percentile for waist circumference. Physical examination shows multiple yellow-pink papules around her elbows and on the back of her thighs. Serum studies show:


Fasting glucose
102 mg/dL


Total cholesterol
347 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
100 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
45 mg/dL


Triglycerides
1012 mg/dL


HbA1c
5.8%


Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is the drug of choice for children and adolescents with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Although this patient has prediabetes (HbA1c 5.8%, fasting glucose 100–125 mg/dL), pharmacotherapy for diabetes is not indicated at this point. This patient requires pharmacotherapy for severe hypertriglyceridemia, for which metformin is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, a second-line treatment for children and adolescents with hypercholesterolemia, also slightly lowers serum triglyceride levels. However, it is not the treatment of choice for a patient with severe hypertriglyceridemia.

C) CORRECT:

While management of children and adolescents with hypertriglyceridemia mainly focuses on lifestyle modification (i.e., promoting a healthy diet, physical activity, and weight loss), pharmacotherapy to reduce the risk of acute pancreatitis should be initiated in patients with triglyceride serum levels >1000 mg/dL and can be considered for patients with serum levels of 400–1000 mg/dL. Fibrates, such as fenofibrate, are the most effective drug for lowering triglyceride serum levels and therefore are the treatment of choice.

Causes of dyslipidemia in children and adolescents include an unhealthy diet (e.g., high in saturated fats), an underlying condition (e.g., obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus), and genetic defects. This patient's presentation with severe hypertriglyceridemia and a family history of dyslipidemia suggests a genetic disorder (e.g., familial hypertriglyceridemia). While hypertriglyceridemia itself is not a strong risk factor for cardiovascular disease, affected patients commonly have other cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., diabetes mellitus, obesity).
Image Description:

A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.

Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.

D) INCORRECT:

Orlistat can be used for weight loss in obese patients and has a favorable effect on serum lipid values. Although this patient might benefit from orlistat, her severely elevated serum triglyceride levels put her at increased risk for acute pancreatitis, so another pharmacotherapy is more appropriate at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Statins (e.g., atorvastatin), the first-line pharmacological treatment for children and adolescents with hypercholesterolemia, are also moderately effective in lowering serum triglyceride levels. However, statins are not the treatment of choice for a patient with severe hypertriglyceridemia.
questions.hint: This obese adolescent presents with features of insulin resistance (impaired fasting glucose), and severe hypertriglyceridemia (> 1000 mg/dL) with eruptive xanthomas. She is at risk for acute triglyceride-induced pancreatitis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of multiple nodules on his hands that first appeared a few months ago. He works as a computer game programmer. His father died of a myocardial infarction at 37 years of age, and his mother has rheumatoid arthritis. A photograph of the lesions is shown. The nodules are firm, mobile, and nontender. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism underlying this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous deposition of triglycerides may been seen in patients with hypertriglyceridemia and results in eruptive xanthomas, which can also cause nontender skin lesions. However, eruptive xanthomas are typically red or yellow soft papules that most commonly develop on the buttocks, back, and extensor surfaces of the extremities. Tendinous xanthomas are not typically associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
Image Description:

A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.

Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis is often seen on histopathologic examination of rheumatoid nodules, the most common cutaneous manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). While this patient's family history of RA puts him at higher risk of developing the condition, he has no other findings that would suggest inflammatory joint disease, such as prolonged morning stiffness and painful symmetrical joint swelling. Furthermore, RA is more common among middle-aged women and is a less likely diagnosis in this young male patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of the hand of an elderly patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

Multiple erythematous subcutaneous nodules are visible at the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints. Involvement of the distal interphalangeal joints and redness are possible but uncommon in patients with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone spurs, or osteophytes, can cause nodular thickening of the proximal interphalangeal joints (Bouchard nodes) and distal interphalangeal joints (Heberden nodes) in patients with osteoarthritis (OA). However, these nodules are typically painful. Additionally, this condition most commonly affects females and usually occurs much later in life, although this patient is at increased risk for developing OA given his occupation (involving repetitive hand movements).
Image Description:

Nodular thickening of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPJ) and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPJ) can be seen.

This appearance is characteristic of bony swellings caused by osteophyte formation in osteoarthritis. At the DIPJ these are called “Heberden nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger and both index fingers), and at the PIPJ they are called “Bouchard nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger).

D) INCORRECT:

Crystallization of monosodium urate in and around the joints cause bone tophi, a classic finding in patients with chronic gout. While tophi are also hard, nontender nodules that can affect the hands, they would be unlikely to form in this young patient who has no history of joint disease. Tophi typically appear in undertreated individuals and take years to develop.
Image Description:

Tophi (monosodium urate crystal deposition in bones and soft tissues) are visible distributed irregularly in the fingers and metacarpus of this patient's left hand.

E) CORRECT:

Tendinous xanthomas form from plasma lipoproteins that have extravasated and accumulated in tendons (most commonly the extensor tendons of the hands and the Achilles tendon) in patients with extremely high levels of circulating lipids. These findings and the death of this patient's father from a myocardial infarction at 37 years of age should raise suspicion for familial hypercholesterolemia, which increases the risk of developing premature coronary artery disease.

Large, perivascular infiltrates with foam cells and Touton giant cells can be seen on histopathological examination of tendinous xanthomas.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tendinous tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are lipid-laden foam cells (histiocytes; examples indicated by arrowheads) and large cholesterol clefts (examples indicated by green overlay) throughout the tissue.

These are typical histological findings in xanthoma.
questions.hint: The firm, skin-colored nodules on the patient's hands are tendinous xanthomas.

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician because of a 6-month history of diarrhea. She has not received recommended well-child examinations. Her stools are foul-smelling and nonbloody. There is no family history of serious illness. She is at the 15th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows abdominal distension. Her serum triglyceride concentration is 5 mg/dL. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the gene that encodes microsomal triglyceride transfer protein. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Avoidance of dairy products is used to treat patients with lactose intolerance. This condition manifests with watery, bulky, and frothy stools (not foul-smelling stools) after the consumption of lactose-containing foods. Moreover, it is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which the avoidance of dairy products has no role in treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid supplementation, in combination with a high-protein diet, is used to treat patients with Hartnup disease. This autosomal recessive condition causes pellagra-like symptoms, which include diarrhea, altered mental status, and a photosensitive rash. It is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which nicotinic acid supplementation has no role in treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Avoidance of dietary gluten is used to treat patients with celiac disease. This condition can cause steatorrhea and failure to thrive, but it is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which the avoidance of dietary gluten has no role in treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Hereditary abetalipoproteinemia results in the absence of production of apolipoprotein B (apo B). Accordingly, no lipoproteins that contain apo B (e.g., chylomicrons, LDL, VLDL) are present in serum, which leads to fat malabsorption. Because dietary intake of fats exacerbates hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, treatment includes a low-fat diet with restriction of long-chain fatty acids. Patients also require supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins.

Late manifestations of hereditary abetalipoproteinemia include retinitis pigmentosa, coagulopathy, myopathy, and spinocerebellar degeneration (due to vitamin E deficiency).

E) INCORRECT:

Long-term antibiotic therapy is used to treat several conditions, including tropical sprue and Whipple disease. Though both of these conditions cause steatorrhea, they typically develop among adults and do not cause failure to thrive in infancy. Moreover, neither of these conditions is associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which long-term antibiotic therapy has no role in treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic enzyme replacement is used to treat patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., due to cystic fibrosis). Pancreatic insufficiency can cause steatorrhea and failure to thrive, but it is not associated with a very low serum triglyceride concentration or a mutation in the gene that encodes MTTP. This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a condition in which pancreatic enzyme replacement has no role in treatment.
questions.hint: This patient has hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, a rare, autosomal recessive condition caused by a mutation in the gene that encodes microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP). Manifestations of this condition include fat malabsorption (which causes steatorrhea and failure to thrive), hepatomegaly (which causes abdominal distension), and very low or absent serum lipid concentrations.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of several episodes of crushing substernal chest pain on exertion over the past 6 weeks. The pain occurs when he goes for his morning run and disappears if he slows down to a walk. The patient is concerned because two of his uncles died of myocardial infarction in their early 50s. Physical examination shows yellow plaques on both of the palms. Serum lipid studies show:


Total cholesterol
650 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
38 mg/dL


VLDL cholesterol
185 mg/dL


Triglycerides
800 mg/dL


Chylomicron remnants
elevated


An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatic overproduction of VLDL is responsible for the pathogenesis of type IV familial hyperlipidemia, which would cause xanthomas, accelerated atherosclerosis, increased VLDL, and hypertriglyceridemia as seen here. However, type IV familial hyperlipidemia is not associated with elevated chylomicron remnants.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased apolipoprotein A-1 is responsible for familial hypoalphalipoproteinemia, which can present with xanthomas and premature atherosclerosis. Although this patient's plasma HDL cholesterol levels are < 40 mg/dL, the hallmark of familial hypoalphalipoproteinemia is severely low plasma HDL cholesterol (usually < 10 mg/dL), which is not evident in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective apolipoprotein B-100 can cause type II familial hyperlipidemia which can manifest with xanthomas, hypercholesterolemia, and early coronary artery disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis. However, elevated chylomicron remnants in serum suggest an alternate diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Apolipoprotein B-48 and apolipoprotein B-100 deficiencies, along with the absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL, are typically seen in abetalipoproteinemia. However, abetalipoproteinemia manifests with steatorrhea and failure to thrive during infancy and complications such as retinitis pigmentosa and progressive ataxia due to vitamin E deficiency. Xanthomas and early coronary artery disease would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased apolipoprotein C-II (apoC-II) causes type I familial hyperlipidemia, which can manifest with hypercholesterolemia and elevated chylomicrons, as seen in this patient. However, type I familial hyperlipidemia does not increase the risk of atherosclerosis.

F) CORRECT:

Type III familial hyperlipidemia (remnant hyperlipidemia) is caused by an autosomal recessive defect in apolipoprotein E (ApoE). ApoE normally mediates the uptake of VLDL and chylomicron remnants into liver cells. Defective ApoE results in the reduced uptake of these lipids, which then causes hyperlipidemia and chylomicronemia. Premature coronary artery disease and peripheral vascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis are common complications in such patients.
questions.hint: This patient with stable angina, palmar xanthomas, hypercholesterolemia, chylomicronemia, and a family history of early myocardial infarction suggests a diagnosis of type III familial hyperlipidemia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the onset of progressively worsening upper abdominal pain and 4 episodes of vomiting. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 40 years. Physical examination shows tenderness and guarding in the epigastrium. Bowel sounds are decreased. His serum amylase is 400 U/L. Symptomatic treatment and therapy with fenofibrate are initiated. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Separate dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salt and pepper skull refers to a characteristic pattern of tiny, radiolucent areas within the calvaria, which classically occurs in the setting of hyperparathyroidism. High calcium levels can lead to premature activation of pancreatic enzymes and therefore pancreatitis. However, as this patient has no mentioned history of hypercalcemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, polyuria, constipation, neuropsychiatric disturbances), salt and pepper skull would be unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral parotid gland enlargement is the hallmark of mumps, of which acute pancreatitis is a rare complication. This patient, however, has not had any classic prodromal findings of mumps, e.g., low-grade fever or malaise. Moreover, fenofibrate would be of no use in mumps-associated pancreatitis, as this complication typically resolves with symptomatic therapy alone.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum ACTH levels can be found in patients with prolonged steroid use, which can lead to exogenous hypercortisolism. Although steroid use is associated with the development of pancreatitis, this patient does not exhibit additional features linked to chronic steroid intake (e.g., truncal obesity, striae, moon facies). In addition, decreased serum ACTH levels due to steroid use would be treated by slowly tapering steroids, not by prescribing fenofibrate.

D) CORRECT:

Eruptive xanthomas occur due to lipid deposition in the dermis and are associated with hypertriglyceridemia. This patient's family history of premature MI further supports hypertriglyceridemia as the underlying cause of his pancreatitis. Treatment generally focuses on dietary restrictions and initiation of fibric acid derivatives, such as fenofibrate.
Image Description:

A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.

Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.

E) INCORRECT:

Separate dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts are characteristic of pancreas divisum, a mostly asymptomatic congenital malformation, in which the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds fail to fuse. Pancreas divisum can occasionally cause pancreatitis but the fact that this patient was treated with fenofibrate suggests a different cause for the patient's symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IgG4 levels occur in the setting of autoimmune pancreatitis, which is associated with other autoimmune disorders such as retroperitoneal fibrosis, Riedel thyroiditis, and non-infectious aortitis. This patient does not have a personal or family history of any of these conditions. Also, autoimmune pancreatitis would be treated with steroids, not fenofibrate.
questions.hint: These findings of worsening epigastric pain with tenderness and guarding in the setting of elevated amylase levels are highly indicative of pancreatitis. The fact that this patient was prescribed fenofibrate indicates that severe hypertriglyceridemia was diagnosed as the underlying cause of his pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of frequent falls, worsening muscle pain, and poor vision in low light conditions. His mother reports that he has been on a low-fat diet since infancy because of persistent diarrhea. He is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows bilateral proximal muscle weakness and a wide ataxic gait. His serum cholesterol level is 21 mg/dL. Peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells with irregular spiny projections of varying size. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

GAA trinucleotide repeats on chromosome 9 are diagnostic of Friedreich ataxia, a hallmark of which is neurologic disability, including progressive ataxia and muscle weakness. While this patient's neuromuscular symptoms could be explained by Friedreich ataxia, persistent diarrhea with malabsorption as the underlying cause is inconsistent with this condition. Moreover, Friedreich ataxia does not alter lipid composition of cellular membranes, which means it does not induce acanthocyte formation.

B) CORRECT:

Post-prandial lipid-laden enterocytes would be expected on a small intestinal biopsy, as impaired chylomicron formation prevents further transport of re-synthesized triglycerides, which then remain stuck in intestinal epithelial cells. This results in extremely low cholesterol levels and failure to transport fat-soluble vitamins into the blood, as observed in this patient. A mutation in the gene that encodes the microsomal transfer protein is the underlying cause of abetalipoproteinemia. This protein is essential to the assembly of apolipoprotein B within enterocytes and hepatocytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Sweat chloride levels > 60 mmol/L are diagnostic of cystic fibrosis, which typically presents with poor development due to fat malabsorption and subsequent deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins. Together with persistent diarrhea, this patient's growth delay and vitamin deficiencies indicate significant malabsorption, which could indeed be attributed to cystic fibrosis. Occasionally, acanthocytes can also be seen in cystic fibrosis (due to vitamin E deficiency). However, the absence of respiratory tract involvement in this patient makes cystic fibrosis less likely. Moreover, the dramatically diminished cholesterol levels in this patient are inconsistent with cystic fibrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies should raise suspicion for celiac disease, which often causes recurrent diarrhea, possibly with malabsorption, which is seen in this patient. Even though extraintestinal manifestations, including ataxia and muscle weakness, may occur in severe cases, acanthocytes on blood testing would be atypical for celiac disease. Moreover, adequate management of celiac disease requires a gluten-free diet rather than one low in fat.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrofatty replacement of muscle tissue is the hallmark of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which leads to significant muscle weakness and ataxia – symptoms that are also present in this patient. However, affected individuals typically present during infancy with calf pseudohypertrophy or the Gower sign rather than persistent diarrhea with malabsorption. Moreover, abnormal blood smear findings would not be expected in a patient with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
questions.hint: This boy has a history consistent with fat malabsorption (persistent diarrhea that improved on a low-fat diet), vitamin E deficiency (muscular weakness and myopathy, spinocerebellar dysfunction), vitamin A deficiency (night blindness), and failure to thrive. Acanthocytes in the blood smear and extremely low cholesterol levels strongly suggest abetalipoproteinemia.

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain at the back of his left ankle. His mother had a myocardial infarction at 54 years. His BMI is 23 kg/m2. There is tenderness above the left posterior calcaneus and a firm, 3-cm, skin-colored nodule that moves with the left Achilles tendon. A photomicrograph from a biopsy of the nodule is shown. Serum studies in this patient are most likely to show increased levels of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is associated with gout, which can manifest cutaneously with nodular tophi. Tophi typically appear on the bones (e.g., elbows, knees, extensor surfaces of forearms) or in soft tissue (e.g., external ear, subcutis, tendon sheaths, or synovial bursas). However, gout would typically also manifest as monoarthritis with acute, severe pain and erythema, decreased range of motion, swelling, and warmth in the affected joint, none of which are present here.
Image Description:

White chalky, nodules in the first and second toes (left)

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor is classically elevated in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can have various extra-articular manifestations, including rheumatoid nodules. However, rheumatoid nodules are not typically associated with tendons. Furthermore, RA is characterized by symmetrical polyarthritis, morning stiffness, and joint deformities, affecting the MCP and PIP joints especially, none of which is seen here. Lastly, RA predominantly affects women and middle-aged individuals rather than teenage males.
Image Description:

Photograph of the hand of an elderly patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

Multiple erythematous subcutaneous nodules are visible at the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints. Involvement of the distal interphalangeal joints and redness are possible but uncommon in patients with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin converting enzyme can be used to assess disease activity in sarcoidosis, which is typically characterized by non-caseating granulomas in the lung but may also manifest with cutaneous granulomas on the face, trunk, and extensor surfaces. However, this patient's lesion is on a tendon, and he does not have any constitutional symptoms of sarcoidosis or any pulmonary symptoms of the disease (e.g., dyspnea, cough), nor does he present with any common extrapulmonary findings (e.g., arthritis, uveitis, lupus pernio).

D) CORRECT:

Tendinous xanthomas indicate particularly high levels of LDL and are commonly associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, in which extremely elevated circulating LDL occurs due to impaired LDL receptor signaling and breakdown. Other cutaneous manifestations of hyperlipidemia include xanthelasma, arcus lipoides corneae, and non-tendinous xanthoma. Familial hypercholesterolemia is associated with premature complications of atherosclerosis, as illustrated by this patient's maternal history of MI at an early age, and intensive lipid-lowering therapy with statins is vital in preventing cardiovascular complications.
Image Description:

Multiple yellowish, smooth nodules are visible on the dorsum of both hands.

This appearance is suggestive of xanthoma tendinosum.

E) INCORRECT:

Hereditary causes of hypertriglyceridemia include type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia), type III hyperlipoproteinemia, and type IV hyperlipidemia (hypertriglyceridemia), none of which are associated with Achilles tendon xanthomas. Type I hyperlipidemia may present with eruptive xanthomas but would not explain the premature atherosclerosis seen in this patient's mother. Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is associated with early atherosclerosis but the xanthomas are more commonly found in the palmar creases, rather than the Achilles tendon xanthoma seen in this patient.
Image Description:

A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.

Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.
questions.hint: The biopsy of the lesion shows multiple lipid-laden foam cells with large cholesterol clefts, suggesting a xanthoma.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. He has a history of stable angina, gout, and hypertension. His medications include lisinopril and aspirin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks 5–6 beers on the weekends. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a total cholesterol of 276 mg/dL with an elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) concentration and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) concentration. Administration of which of the following agents is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B3 (niacin) is a lipid-lowering agent synthesized from tryptophan that decreases hepatic VLDL synthesis and inhibits the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase. It increases HDL levels and, to a lesser degree, reduces triglyceride and LDL synthesis. However, it is not considered a first-line monotherapy in patients with hyperlipidemia and it is not recommended in patients with gout because of the associated risk of hyperuricemia.

B) CORRECT:

HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors, more commonly referred to as statins, are the first-line treatment for hyperlipidemia. Statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis in the liver by inhibiting the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate. Statins are the most effective drug for reducing LDL levels, and they also increase HDL and lower triglyceride levels. Common side effects of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors include elevated LFTs and myalgias (especially when used concomitantly with fibrates).

C) INCORRECT:

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α) activators are more commonly referred to as fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate). The activation of PPAR-α increases lipoprotein lipase production, fatty acid uptake, and oxidation as well as HDL synthesis. Fibrates are most effective at decreasing triglyceride levels and increasing HDL levels and only have a mild effect on LDL levels. For this reason, fibrates would not be recommended as monotherapy in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol absorption inhibitors like ezetimibe decrease LDL by inhibiting cholesterol absorption at the brush borders of the small intestine. However, ezetimibe is considered a second-line lipid-lowering agent. It is reserved for patients who do not tolerate the first-line drug and would not be the first choice for this patient. Side effects of ezetimibe include diarrhea and increased LFTs.

E) INCORRECT:

PCSK9 inhibitors such as alirocumab and evolocumab work by inhibiting the degradation of LDL receptors, which decreases circulating LDL levels. However, they are currently only recommended as an adjunct treatment in patients in whom first-line therapy has failed. Side effects include myalgias, delirium, and cognitive impairment.

F) INCORRECT:

Bile acid resins such as cholestyramine lower plasma LDL cholesterol levels by binding to bile acid and preventing its reabsorption in the gastrointestinal tract, thereby increasing intestinal LDL losses (which is bound to bile salts). Bile acid resins are not considered a first-line therapy for hyperlipidemia because of their gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., diarrhea) and the fact they lower LDL only minimally.
questions.hint: This patient has hyperlipidemia and a history that suggests coronary artery disease (stable angina).

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Early detection and treatment of hyperlipidemia is crucial to prevent ASCVD events like stroke or myocardial infarction. The guidelines for hyperlipidemia screening differ slightly among various expert groups. The current consensus is to screen all individuals aged 20–75 years using a fasting or nonfasting serum lipid profile test every 4–6 years in patients without additional ASCVD risk factors and at more frequent intervals in those with additional ASCVD risk factors.

See “Screening recommendations for men by age” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia and gonorrhea are the most common causes of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID is most often asymptomatic, it can result in severe complications, including infertility and ectopic pregnancy. Therefore, both the USPSTF and CDC recommend annual screening with a nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active women < 25 years and women ≥ 25 years with certain risk factors (e.g., new or multiple sex partners, a sex partner with an STI). The CDC also recommends annual screening for both sexually active HIV-positive men and men who have sex with men because of the higher incidence of gonorrhea and chlamydia infections in these populations. Routine chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is not currently recommended for sexually active, HIV-negative men in monogamous, heterosexual relationships, such as this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The AHA and other expert groups do recommend screening for a certain disease in this patient's age group.

D) INCORRECT:

The guidelines for prostate cancer screening differ slightly among various expert groups but the USPSTF recommends screening men aged 55–69 years with a life expectancy of at least 10 years after informing the patient of the benefits as well as risks of prostate cancer screening (e.g., relatively high false-positive rate, additional unnecessary procedures), i.e., by employing a shared decision-making strategy. Prostate cancer screening is most commonly performed using a serum prostate-specific antigen test every 2 years. Screening can be initiated earlier at 40 years for patients with a first-degree relative who developed early-onset prostate cancer (i.e., before 65 years). This 42-year-old patient with a second-degree relative who developed prostate cancer at the age of 73 years does not require prostate cancer screening at this visit.

E) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient evidence to recommend routine screening for osteoporosis in men, but screening can be considered in men with strong risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use; androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer) and in men ≥ 70 years of age. In this 42-year old man without such risk factors, screening for osteoporosis is not recommended.
questions.hint: Screening for this disorder is recommended by the American Heart Association and various other expert groups for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD).

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. She has a past history of cigarette smoking and no family history of premature coronary heart disease. She has no symptoms of angina, carotid disease, or peripheral vascular disease. Her current medications are hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, lisinopril 10 mg daily, metformin 500 mg twice daily, and atorvastatin 20 mg daily.
She has a blood pressure of 145/94 mm Hg (similar to several recent readings at home) and a heart rate of 77 beats per minute. Heart and lung auscultation is normal. There is evidence of neuropathy on monofilament testing of the lower extremities.
Fasting lipid testing reveals a total cholesterol level of 200 mg/dL, an LDL-cholesterol level of 84 mg/dL, and an HDL-cholesterol level of 71 mg/dL. The patient’s baseline LDL-cholesterol 3 months ago, before starting atorvastatin, was 130 mg/dL.
What change(s), if any, should be made to this patient’s medication regimen?

choices.text: Increase the dose of lisinopril; switch atorvastatin to rosuvastatin
No change to lisinopril or atorvastatin
No change to lisinopril; increase the dose of atorvastatin
Increase the doses of both lisinopril and atorvastatin
Switch lisinopril to enalapril; no change to the dose of atorvastatin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Switching from atorvastatin to rosuvastatin is not indicated, as the patient is tolerating atorvastatin and has room to increase the dose to higher intensity.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated.

This patient will also require an increase in her statin dose.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated.

D) CORRECT:

According to current hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA), patients with type 2 diabetes who develop hypertension should start treatment at blood pressures (BPs) ≥130/80 and be treated to a target BP of <130/80 mm Hg. The American Diabetes Association recommends individualizing the BP target through a shared decision-making process, but using this same target of <130/80 mm Hg in most patients, assuming it can be safely attained. This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated. She will most likely need a third antihypertensive medication to reach her target BP and should therefore follow up within one month of starting a higher dose of lisinopril, to reassess her BP response.

This patient will also require an increase in her statin dose. According to the current ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guideline, all adults aged 40 to 75 who have type 2 diabetes should receive, at a minimum, a moderate-intensity statin (e.g., atorvastatin 10–20 mg daily, rosuvastatin 5–10 mg daily, pravastatin 40–80 mg daily, lovastatin 40–80 mg, or simvastatin 20–40 mg daily), regardless of their estimated atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. If a patient has multiple ASCVD risk factors (as in this case: age >60 years, hypertension, past smoking history, and diabetes-specific risk enhancers such as neuropathy), it is reasonable to attempt to lower the LDL-cholesterol level by ≥50% and to target an LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL by either intensifying therapy to a high-dose statin (e.g., atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily, rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily) or adding other agents such as ezetimibe or a proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 (PCSK9) serine protease inhibitor. This patient’s LDL-cholesterol level has decreased by only 35% (from 130 mg/dL to 84 mg/dL) since she started a moderate-dose statin, and it remains above 70 mg/dL. The atorvastatin dose should therefore be increased.

Key learning point: In patients with type 2 diabetes, the target blood pressure is <130/80 mm Hg, and the goal for lipid-lowering therapy is to reduce the LDL-cholesterol level by ≥50% from baseline to a target level of <70 mg/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

Switching from lisinopril to enalapril is not indicated, as the patient is tolerating lisinopril and has room to increase the dose.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with no known medical history is hospitalized and treated for an acute coronary syndrome. On admission, she is noted to have obesity and nodularity of her Achilles tendons. Her father died suddenly in his early fifties.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
223
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
46
≥46



Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
303
125–200



Triglycerides (mg/dL)
171
<150


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
5.4
0.5–4.7


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertriglyceridemia is associated with cardiovascular disease but does not result in xanthomas or a severely elevated LDL-cholesterol level.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is characterized by an elevated serum triglyceride level but low levels of HDL and LDL cholesterol.

C) INCORRECT:

Combined hyperlipidemia (manifest by hypercholesterolemia and hypertriglyceridemia) is not associated with a markedly elevated serum LDL-cholesterol level or with xanthomas.

D) CORRECT:

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by markedly elevated levels of serum LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol. The diagnosis of heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia can be confirmed by genetic testing but is frequently made clinically in patients with a total cholesterol level ranging from 350 to 550 mg/dL or an LDL-cholesterol level ranging from 200 to 400 mg/dL. Tendinous xanthomas, as evident on this patient’s Achilles tendons, are pathognomonic for the diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia and are not found in secondary causes of hypercholesterolemia.

Familial hypercholesterolemia is often undiagnosed until an acute coronary syndrome or other cardiovascular event occurs. The patient’s family history often includes premature cardiovascular disease in first-degree relatives.

Key learning point: Tendinous xanthomas are pathognomonic for the diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism, a frequent cause of hyperlipidemia typically associated with a high serum LDL cholesterol levels, is not associated with xanthomas.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with long-standing HIV has lipodystrophy that he thinks is most likely related to a previous antiretroviral regimen.
Prolonged treatment in the past with which one of the following medications is the most likely cause of lipodystrophy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Older medications used in the treatment of HIV infection were associated with antiretroviral-associated lipodystrophy. This condition manifests with symptoms and physical examination findings that can mimic Cushing syndrome, such as weight gain, truncal obesity, peripheral wasting, and dorsocervical fat deposition.

Antiretroviral-associated lipodystrophy is most commonly associated with the use of protease inhibitors, such as saquinavir. Certain nucleoside reverse-transcriptase inhibitors, such as zidovudine, may also contribute to this syndrome, particularly lipoatrophy of the face and limbs. Patients with lipodystrophy often have gynecomastia, as well as increased risks for heart disease, insulin resistance, and hyperlipidemia.

Key learning point: Among antiretroviral medications, the subclass most typically associated with lipodystrophy is protease inhibitors.

B) INCORRECT:

Lamivudine, raltegravir, rilpivirine, and emtricitabine are not considered to be causes of lipodystrophy.

C) INCORRECT:

Lamivudine, raltegravir, rilpivirine, and emtricitabine are not considered to be causes of lipodystrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Lamivudine, raltegravir, rilpivirine, and emtricitabine are not considered to be causes of lipodystrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Lamivudine, raltegravir, rilpivirine, and emtricitabine are not considered to be causes of lipodystrophy.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents for routine follow-up. She takes no medications, does not smoke, and has no known family history of hyperlipidemia. She has a BMI of 28.8, a blood pressure of 129/83 mm Hg, and a heart rate of 88 beats per minute. Her physical examination is otherwise normal.
In her records, a lipid panel from 2 years ago shows the following results:



Patient value


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
237


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
157


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
54


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
130


Assuming this patient's health remains unchanged, when should her lipid levels be remeasured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adults aged 40 to 75 without clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or diabetes mellitus who have a serum LDL-cholesterol level of 70 to 189 mg/dL and are not receiving cholesterol-lowering drug therapy should have their lipid levels measured every 4 to 6 years, so that their 10-year risk of ASCVD can be recalculated. In this case, the patient had a lipid assessment 2 years ago and should therefore be reevaluated within the next 2 to 4 years to be within the recommended window.

B) CORRECT:

Adults aged 40 to 75 without clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or diabetes mellitus who have a serum LDL-cholesterol level of 70 to 189 mg/dL and are not receiving cholesterol-lowering drug therapy should have their lipid levels measured every 4 to 6 years, so that their 10-year risk of ASCVD can be recalculated. In this case, the patient had a lipid assessment 2 years ago and should therefore be reevaluated within the next 2 to 4 years to be within the recommended window. Waiting longer than that (such as when she reaches age 50 or becomes postmenopausal) is not appropriate given that her LDL-cholesterol level is already borderline high.

Key learning point: The recommended frequency of lipid screening for a patient aged 40 to 75 with a borderline elevated LDL-cholesterol level is every 4 to 6 years.

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

Although clinicians should consider monitoring lipid levels in patients who are taking a statin, there is no indication to start a statin in this patient at this time (her current clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk is 0.9%). For those patients with a 10-year clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk of 7.5% or higher despite lifestyle modification, statin therapy should be initiated in the context of a risk discussion.

E) INCORRECT:

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, as well as hypertension and hyperlipidemia, reports a 1-month history of several new skin lesions. She has had no fevers, chills, or joint pain. Her current medications are insulin, metformin, labetalol, simvastatin, and a multivitamin.
The skin lesions are reddish-yellow, pruritic, and painful. They are present on the backs of both legs and on the buttocks and knees (figures 1 and 2).
Laboratory testing reveals a glycated hemoglobin level of 11.9% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). The patient’s complete blood count, electrolytes, and kidney function are normal.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin lesions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis is characterized by tanning of the skin, not by discrete eruptive lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Easy skin bruising and purple or red striae are the common skin findings of Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Familial combined hypercholesterolemia is a disorder associated with an elevated level of LDL cholesterol; it is associated with xanthomas of the tendons and around the eyes (xanthelasmas).

D) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis is characterized by abnormal skin pigmentation (café au lait spots) and skin fibromas.

E) CORRECT:

Eruptive xanthomatosis — the appearance of reddish-yellow papular skin lesions on an erythematous base, concentrated mainly on extensor surfaces of the extremities — is primarily caused by severe hypertriglyceridemia. The disorder usually responds well to triglyceride-lowering treatment, and complete resolution of the lesions is common.

Extremely elevated triglyceride levels (>2000 mg/dL) are associated with lipemic serum and an increased risk for pancreatitis, typically called chylomicronemia syndrome. Funduscopic examination may reveal lipemic retinal vessels consistent with chylomicrons. Severe hypertriglyceridemia is usually caused by a common genetic form of hypertriglyceridemia combined with an acquired disorder, most often type 2 diabetes that is untreated or poorly controlled.

Key learning point: Reddish-yellow papules concentrated primarily on the extensor surfaces of the legs in a patient with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes are most indicative of eruptive xanthomatosis, which occurs in patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman reports that she has noticed a change in the skin around her eyes. She has a history of three-vessel coronary artery disease and had coronary artery bypass graft surgery 10 years ago. She also has a history of hypertension and impaired fasting glucose. She has several family members with early-onset coronary disease. Her medications include a high-dose statin, aspirin, atenolol, and lisinopril.
On examination, she has fusiform, yellowish, nontender plaques surrounding both eyes (figure). She says she has had the plaques for many years.
Which one of the following lipid abnormalities is most likely to explain this patient’s physical findings?

choices.text: Low levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol
Elevated levels of very-low-density lipoprotein cholesterol
Elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Xanthelasma are more typically associated with high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol than with low levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, elevated levels of very-low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, or elevated free fatty acids.

B) INCORRECT:

Xanthelasma are more typically associated with high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol than with low levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, elevated levels of very-low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, or elevated free fatty acids.

C) INCORRECT:

Xanthelasma are more typically associated with high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol than with low levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, elevated levels of very-low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, or elevated free fatty acids.

D) CORRECT:

Xanthelasma are chronic, nontender plaques that contain cholesterol-rich macrophages and appear as fusiform, yellowish nontender plaques surrounding the eyes. They tend to be more frequent in women than in men and can appear at all ages, with a peak incidence at the fourth and fifth decades of life. Xanthelasma palpebrarum, the most common type of skin xanthoma, is highly prevalent in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia who have significantly elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol. However, some patients with xanthelasma palpebrarum have no detectable lipid abnormality.

Key learning point: The lipid fraction that is most typically elevated in patients with xanthalesma is the low-density lipoprotein cholesterol level.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated triglycerides (primarily chylomicrons) may lead to acute and tender cutaneous eruptive xanthoma, but not xanthelasma.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man whose father passed away from a myocardial infarction at age 40 and whose brother suffered a myocardial infarction at age 33 is seeking a cardiovascular risk assessment. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. He has never smoked and reports only occasional alcohol use.
He weighs 77 kg and has a BMI of 25.8. His abdominal circumference is 89 cm. His seated blood pressure is 116/75 mm Hg with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute. On examination, he has scattered yellowish plaques in his palmar creases bilaterally.
Fasting laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
82
75–100


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
5.2
4.3–5.6


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
426
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
315
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
48
≥40


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
310
<150


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
0.9
0.5–4.7


The patient’s complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and renal function tests are normal.
Which one of the following conditions is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The metabolic syndrome is defined as a large waist circumference (≥102 cm or 40 inches for men; ≥88 cm or 36 inches for women) plus two of the following features: an elevated triglyceride level, a low HDL-cholesterol level, hyperglycemia, or hypertension. This patient has hypertriglyceridemia but does not meet any of the other criteria.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is a cause of severe primary hypertriglyceridemia, but it is not associated with an elevated LDL-cholesterol level.

C) INCORRECT:

Familial hypertriglyceridemia is not associated with palmar xanthomas, increased LDL cholesterol, or an increased risk of premature coronary artery disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Although familial hypercholesterolemia is associated with an elevated LDL-cholesterol level and xanthomas, it is also associated with a normal triglyceride level and xanthelasma.

E) CORRECT:

Dysbetalipoproteinemia (formerly called type III hyperlipoproteinemia) is a rare lipid disorder associated with elevated triglyceride and LDL-cholesterol levels. The condition carries a risk of premature cardiovascular and peripheral vascular disease. Xanthomas are common in affected individuals; palmar xanthomas, typically found in the palmar creases, are pathognomonic for this disorder.

Key learning point: Palmar xanthomas are pathognomonic for the diagnosis of dysbetalipoproteinemia (formerly called type III hyperlipoproteinemia).

questions.text:
A 38-year-old asymptomatic woman with a history of obesity presents for follow-up regarding her recent laboratory tests. She is not taking any medications. Her mother is being treated for hypothyroidism and type 2 diabetes. There is no known family history of heart disease or stroke.
Fasting laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
2.2
0.5–4.7


Glucose (mg/dL)
245
70–100


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
8.3
4.3–5.6


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
216
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
96
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
45
≥46


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
375
<150


In addition to recommending lifestyle modification for her obesity, which one of the following medications should this patient initiate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin has not been shown to reduce cardiovascular events in people with type 2 diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate has failed to show a reduction in the risk for coronary events among patients with type 2 diabetes.

If the patient’s triglyceride level exceeded 1000 mg/dL, she would be at risk for pancreatitis, which would warrant more-urgent treatment, most often with a fibrate.

C) INCORRECT:

At least moderate-intensity statin therapy is recommended for all patients with diabetes mellitus who are age 40 to 75 years; high-intensity therapy is a reasonable choice for those who have additional risk enhancers for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), such as increasing age, increasing duration of diabetes, and family history of premature ASCVD. This patient does not meet criteria for statin therapy.

D) CORRECT:

The first step to managing hypertriglyceridemia is to identify potential secondary causes. If such a cause is identified, it is appropriate to reevaluate the lipid profile after this secondary cause is addressed. Hypertriglyceridemia can be caused by hyperglycemia and would be expected to improve substantially once glycemic control is achieved.

In a patient with type 2 diabetes (e.g., with a glycated hemoglobin level ≥6.5%) and hyperglycemia, metformin is appropriate for initial treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. Statin therapy can be added if the patient’s triglyceride level remains elevated after achievement of glycemic control.

Key learning point: The most effective approach to managing hypertriglyceridemia in a patient with uncontrolled and untreated type 2 diabetes is to control the hyperglycemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism is another cause of secondary hypertriglyceridemia; however, this patient’s thyroid-stimulating hormone level is normal. In general, treatment with levothyroxine is initiated on the basis of symptoms of hypothyroidism or if the thyroid-stimulating hormone level is greater than 10 μU/mL. Inadequately treated hypothyroidism is most typically associated with an elevated LDL-cholesterol level but can also cause mixed hyperlipidemia or hypertriglyceridemia alone.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents with papules on his knuckles and elbows that have grown gradually over time (figure). He reports no trauma to the affected areas, no pain associated with the papules, and no history of pain elsewhere in his upper or lower extremities. His family history includes type 2 diabetes in his father and a history of a myocardial infarction in both parents. He has limited information about his extended family’s medical history. His examination is unremarkable other than the skin changes.
Which one of the following laboratory tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this case?

choices.text: Serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A rheumatoid factor test is used to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis, which causes other types of joint changes, such as ulnar deviation.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels are used to diagnose hyperparathyroidism, which may be associated with brown tumors, usually in the long bones, ribs, and jaw.

C) INCORRECT:

A uric acid test helps diagnose tophaceous gout, which causes considerable focal pain with gout flares.

D) INCORRECT:

An insulin-like growth factor 1 test is used to diagnose acromegaly.

E) CORRECT:

Yellowish tuberosities (xanthomas) over extensor surfaces are a physical manifestation of familial hypercholesterolemia. A lipid profile is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

The other tests listed are unlikely to be diagnostic given that the patient’s examination is unremarkable other than the tuberosities.

Key learning point: In a patient with familial hypercholesterolemia, a physical sign of an elevated LDL cholesterol level is xanthomas.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman reports increasing fatigue and a 4.5-kg weight gain during the past 5 months. She has been trying to improve her diet by eliminating fast food and increasing her vegetable intake. She has also joined a gym and exercises for 30 minutes every day; however, her weight continues to rise. She does not smoke. Her father died from a myocardial infarction at age 43.
On examination, the patient has a heart rate of 62 beats per minute, and her voice is hoarse. She has a small, homogenous thyroid gland.
Fasting laboratory testing yields the following results:

Which one of the following interventions is most appropriate?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with liothyronine is not recommended for long-term treatment of hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Simvastatin and fenofibrate are not first-line treatments for lipid abnormalities that are likely to be primarily attributable to hypothyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Simvastatin and fenofibrate are not first-line treatments for lipid abnormalities that are likely to be primarily attributable to hypothyroidism.

D) CORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause a constellation of symptoms, including fatigue and weight gain. On physical examination, patients may have bradycardia, delayed upstroke of deep-tendon reflexes, or an enlarged thyroid gland.

Patients with primary hypothyroidism often have dyslipidemia, which may be primary or an exacerbation of genetic lipid abnormalities. That is because thyroid hormones upregulate or stimulate several enzymes involved with lipid metabolism and also upregulate LDL receptors. Thyroid hormone deficiency results in variable elevations of total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides; HDL cholesterol may remain normal or become elevated. Treating hypothyroidism with levothyroxine would be expected to improve or normalize the lipid profile.

Key learning point: Overt hypothyroidism can manifest with lipid abnormalities, including elevated levels of LDL cholesterol, triglycerides, total cholesterol, and HDL cholesterol.

E) INCORRECT:

Dietary changes would not resolve the lipid changes seen in patients with hypothyroidism.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man is seen for follow-up of an abnormal lipid profile. His father has a history of hyperlipidemia. The patient does not smoke and drinks one beer per week. He is married and has a 2-year-old son.
On examination, his blood pressure is 118/64 mm Hg, and his weight is 100 kg, an increase of 11 kg from the previous year. He is muscular and tanned. His testes are 10 cc in size (reference range, 15–25).
Laboratory testing yields the following results:
