Use of which one of the following products is the most likely cause of this patient's laboratory abnormalities?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supplements such as growth hormone, creatine monohydrate, vitamin A, and taurine do not cause hypogonadism or low HDL-cholesterol levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Supplements such as growth hormone, creatine monohydrate, vitamin A, and taurine do not cause hypogonadism or low HDL-cholesterol levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Supplements such as growth hormone, creatine monohydrate, vitamin A, and taurine do not cause hypogonadism or low HDL-cholesterol levels.

D) CORRECT:

Recreational use of anabolic steroids can have a variety of adverse effects. It can cause hypogonadism through central suppression of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, leading to small testes. Anabolic steroids can also cause very low HDL-cholesterol levels and elevations in LDL cholesterol, total cholesterol, and triglyceride levels. Androgen use leads to low HDL-cholesterol levels by enhancing hepatic lipase, which processes HDL cholesterol into smaller, denser particles that are more rapidly broken down. One to 3 months after anabolic steroid withdrawal, the lipid measurements normalize.

An apparent recent increase in lean muscle mass and a low HDL-cholesterol level in a man who has fathered a child is most consistent with the use of anabolic steroids. Anabolic steroid use results in suppression of the gonadotropin hormones that maintain testicular mass.

Key learning point: The combination of small testes, increased muscle mass, and a very low HDL-cholesterol level implies recreational use of anabolic steroids.

E) INCORRECT:

Supplements such as growth hormone, creatine monohydrate, vitamin A, and taurine do not cause hypogonadism or low HDL-cholesterol levels.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents for follow-up. He was hospitalized 6 months ago with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction requiring stent placement to his left anterior descending artery. He also has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and former tobacco use. He has remained abstinent from smoking since the hospitalization.
At his last appointment 3 months ago, he was started on ezetimibe 10 mg daily. His other current medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, lisinopril 40 mg daily, carvedilol 12.5 mg twice daily, metformin 1000 mg twice daily, insulin glargine and aspart, empagliflozin 25 mg daily, semaglutide 1 mg weekly, rosuvastatin 40 mg daily, ezetimibe 10 mg daily, and varenicline 1 mg twice daily. He reports feeling well today without any cardiac symptoms.
His physical examination is normal with vital signs notable for a BMI of 32, blood pressure of 128/73 mm Hg, and heart rate of 62 beats per minute.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
180
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
109
<130


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
120
<150


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
47
≥40


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
6.9%
3.8–5.6


A recent echocardiogram showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%.
Which one of the following medication changes is indicated to reduce this patient’s risk for future cardiovascular events?

choices.text: Increase the dose of carvedilol to 25 mg twice daily
Increase the dose of ezetimibe to 20 mg daily
Switch rosuvastatin to atorvastatin 80 mg daily
Start icosapent ethyl 2 g twice daily

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient is at very high risk for recurrent cardiovascular events given his prior myocardial infarction; thus, maximal control of risk factors is indicated. His blood pressure is currently at goal (thus, there is no role for increasing carvedilol, especially because his heart rate is already low-normal), and he has quit smoking. The main remaining modifiable risk factor is his hyperlipidemia.

Current guidelines recommend that high-risk patients initiate a high-intensity statin with a goal of achieving at least a 50% reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels and ideally an LDL-cholesterol level <70 mg/dL. If this goal is not achieved with a statin alone, or if maximal statin therapy is not tolerated, then ezetimibe (at a maximal dose of 10 mg daily) can be added. If the LDL-cholesterol level remains >70 mg/dL despite these two agents, as in this case, then a proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 (PCSK9) inhibitor, such as evolocumab, should be considered.

PCSK9 inhibitors are injectable agents taken either every other week or once a month. They are indicated as an adjunct to diet and maximally tolerated statin therapy for patients with familial hyperlipidemia or clinical cardiovascular disease who require additional lowering of LDL-cholesterol levels. These agents inhibit the enzyme PCSK9, which is predominantly produced in the liver and binds to the LDL-cholesterol receptor on the surface of hepatocytes. This binding leads to degradation of the LDL-cholesterol receptor, which subsequently raises plasma LDL-cholesterol levels. Therefore, elevated levels of PCSK9 have been associated with higher LDL-cholesterol levels and with worse cardiovascular outcomes. PCSK9 inhibitors interfere with the binding of PCSK9 to the LDL-cholesterol receptor, thus leading to higher hepatic LDL-cholesterol-receptor expression and lower plasma LDL-cholesterol levels. This has been found to reduce the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events. Major adverse effects of the medication are injection-site reactions and allergic or hypersensitivity reactions.

Key learning point: Patients at very high risk for cardiovascular events who are on maximally tolerated statin and ezetimibe therapy but do not achieve a reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels >50% and an LDL-cholesterol level <70 mg/dL can further reduce their cardiovascular risk by adding a proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 (PCSK9) inhibitor to their regimen.

B) INCORRECT:

His blood pressure is currently at goal (thus, there is no role for increasing carvedilol, especially because his heart rate is already low-normal), and he has quit smoking. The main remaining modifiable risk factor is his hyperlipidemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines recommend that high-risk patients initiate a high-intensity statin with a goal of achieving at least a 50% reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels and ideally an LDL-cholesterol level <70 mg/dL. If this goal is not achieved with a statin alone, or if maximal statin therapy is not tolerated, then ezetimibe (at a maximal dose of 10 mg daily) can be added. If the LDL-cholesterol level remains >70 mg/dL despite these two agents, as in this case, then a PCSK9 inhibitor should be considered. Increasing the dose of ezetimibe beyond the maximal dose is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient is already on a high-intensity statin (rosuvastatin) at maximum dose, so switching to another statin will likely be ineffective.

E) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl can be used for risk reduction in patients with cardiovascular disease whose LDL-cholesterol levels are <100 mg/dL but whose triglyceride levels are persistently elevated at >135 mg/dL. This patient does not fit these criteria.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents for a routine visit. She reports feeling well overall and engages in moderate-intensity aerobic exercise for 30 minutes three times per week. She is interested in further reducing her cardiovascular risk. She has a history of hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes. Her current medications include rosuvastatin 40 mg daily and metformin 500 mg twice daily.
Her blood pressure is 122/68 mm Hg, her heart rate is 72 beats per minute, and her BMI is 26.6. She appears well, and her cardiac and lung examination is within normal limits.
Laboratory testing under fasting conditions yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
140
125–200


LDL-cholesterol (mg/dL)
65
<130


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
249
<150


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
6.6
3.8–5.6


Which one of the following medications is indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, is an antidiabetic agent that can help with glycemic control. In this case, the patient’s blood glucose level is already at target, based on her glycated hemoglobin level, so further glucose lowering is not needed. Pioglitazone may have beneficial cardiovascular effects, but the evidence for this is not strong and pioglitazone is generally not used for this indication.

B) INCORRECT:

Niacin has been shown to reduce triglyceride levels, but systematic review has not demonstrated an effect on improving all-cause mortality, cardiovascular mortality, or myocardial infarction outcomes. Niacin is therefore not indicated in this case.

C) CORRECT:

This patient, who has persistently elevated fasting triglyceride levels (>135 mg/dL) while taking a statin, may benefit from the addition of icosapent ethyl to her regimen. The benefits of this medication for this purpose were demonstrated in a multicenter, randomized, placebo-controlled trial known as REDUCE-IT.

In the REDUCE-IT trial, researchers enrolled more than 8000 patients who had elevated fasting triglyceride levels (135–499 mg/dL) and LDL-cholesterol levels between 41 and 100 mg/dL while taking a statin. All of the study participants were considered to be at high cardiovascular risk for one of two reasons: (1) established cardiovascular disease or (2) type 2 diabetes plus at least one additional risk factor. These additional risk factors included age (men ≥55, women ≥65), history of tobacco use, hypertension, low HDL-cholesterol levels (≤40 mg/dL for men, ≤50 mg/dL for women), high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels >3 mg/liter, renal dysfunction, retinopathy, or an ankle-brachial index <0.9 with claudication. Patients were randomized to receive either icosapent ethyl 2 g twice daily or placebo, with median follow-up of 4.9 years. The primary outcome — a composite of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, coronary revascularization, or unstable angina — occurred in 17.2% of patients in the icosapent ethyl group compared with 22.0% in the placebo group, a significant difference. However, hospitalization for atrial fibrillation or flutter was more common in the icosapent ethyl group (3.1% vs. 2.1%), as was the risk of a serious bleeding event (2.7% vs. 2.1%). Given these trial results, icosapent ethyl is recommended for cardiovascular risk reduction in patients at high risk who have persistently elevated fasting triglyceride levels (>135 mg/dL) despite statin therapy.

Key learning point: In patients at high risk for cardiovascular disease who are already taking a statin, the risk for cardiovascular events can be further reduced by lowering triglyceride levels with icosapent ethyl.

D) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate is used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia but has not been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events. It is therefore generally used only to reduce the risk of pancreatitis, which becomes significant only with triglyceride levels >500 to 1000 mg/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe has not been shown to reduce triglyceride levels. It can be used for further LDL-cholesterol reduction primarily in patients with known atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who do not meet their LDL target, which would not fit this patient scenario.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to clinic for follow-up. She has a history of tobacco use, hypertension, dyslipidemia, obesity, type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism, and coronary artery disease complicated by a non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (MI) 3 years ago that required stent placement. She currently feels well and reports no symptoms.
At the time of her MI, she was started on atorvastatin 80 mg daily. However, she self-discontinued the medication after experiencing significant myalgias and stiffness with exercise that persisted despite reducing the dose to 10 mg daily and trying every-other-day dosing. Her creatine kinase levels at the time were normal. She subsequently tried pravastatin 10 mg every other day and rosuvastatin 2.5 mg weekly but experienced similar symptoms. In each case, the symptoms resolved after she discontinued the statin. At her last visit 3 months ago, she was started on ezetimibe 10 mg daily. Since that visit, she has also quit smoking and has lost 5 kg with diet and exercise; she does not drink alcohol.
Her current medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, carvedilol 12.5 mg twice daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, metformin 1000 mg twice daily, semaglutide 1 mg weekly, ezetimibe 10 mg daily, and levothyroxine 75 μg daily.
Her blood pressure is 118/74 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 68 beats per minute. Her physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
176
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
106
<130


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
110
<150


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
38
≥46


Thyroid stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
3.2
0.5–4.7


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
40
30–80


Which one of the following medications is indicated to further reduce this patient’s cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with a history of coronary artery disease, aggressive LDL-lowering therapies are indicated to achieve an LDL-cholesterol level <70 mg/dL. High-intensity statin therapy is typically used in this setting, but if the goal LDL-cholesterol level is not achieved with the highest tolerated statin dose, then the clinician can consider adding ezetimibe, a proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 (PCSK9) inhibitor such as alirocumab, or both.

Statin-Associated Myopathy

Some patients cannot tolerate high-intensity statin therapy, usually because of myalgias or, occasionally, muscle weakness. In patients experiencing such symptoms, the first step is to consider alternative explanations for the symptoms or the possibility of other factors causing or exacerbating the intolerance. For example:

• Alcohol is a common culprit that interferes with the body’s elimination of statins, so minimizing alcohol use is essential.
• Some commonly prescribed cardiac medications, such as amiodarone and diltiazem, can interfere with statin metabolism.
• Low vitamin D levels have been associated with statin-related myopathy in some studies.

If none of the above are implicated (as in this case, where the patient does not drink alcohol, take any culprit medications, or have low vitamin D levels), the next step is to transition the patient to a different type of statin. Although patients and clinicians might be tempted to abandon statins as a drug class if a single drug is not effective or causes adverse effects, this would deprive the patient of the well-documented benefits of the drug class in reducing the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. A better strategy is to transition the patient to a hydrophilic statin (rosuvastatin, pravastatin), as these agents are less likely to cause myalgias than lipophilic statins (simvastatin, atorvastatin, lovastatin); once-weekly dosing is recommended to start, with slow titration upward as tolerated. Rosuvastatin is favored for this intermittent-dosing approach because it has a longer half-life. In this case, the patient has tried hydrophilic statins at intermittent lower-dose intervals without success and can now be considered to have statin intolerance.

Statin intolerance is defined by the American College of Cardiology as documented unacceptable muscle-related symptoms that resolve with discontinuation of therapy and occur with rechallenge on at least two to three statins, preferably ones that use different metabolic pathways and have different lipophilicity, and one of which is prescribed at the lowest approved dose. Of note, most patients do not have complete statin intolerance; many are able to tolerate low-dose statin therapy, but often the doses are too low to achieve the low LDL-cholesterol levels that are targeted in high-risk patients. The next step in such patients is initiation of ezetimibe.

Ezetimibe inhibits absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine, leading to decreased delivery of cholesterol to the liver, reduction in hepatic cholesterol stores, and increased clearance of circulating cholesterol. Ezetimibe reduces LDL-cholesterol levels by about 15%; it is therefore not uncommon for LDL-cholesterol levels to remain above target with ezetimibe alone. If ezetimibe in combination with the highest tolerated statin dose does not result in goal LDL-cholesterol levels, as in this patient, then a PCSK9 inhibitor is indicated.

PCSK9 is an enzyme that binds to the LDL-cholesterol receptor on the surface of hepatocytes, leading to degradation of the LDL-cholesterol receptor and subsequent higher LDL-cholesterol levels. Evolocumab and alirocumab are monoclonal antibodies that bind free plasma PCSK9, promoting enzyme degradation, leading to increased concentration of LDL-cholesterol receptors and increased hepatic clearance of LDL-cholesterol particles, thus reducing circulating LDL-cholesterol levels. The end result is lower plasma LDL-cholesterol levels. In the GAUSS-2 trial, researchers evaluated PCSK9 inhibitor therapy in patients with statin intolerance and found an absolute reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels (mean reduction, 55%) with a low rate of muscle-related adverse effects and a good overall adverse-effect profile.

This patient has statin intolerance and is already taking ezetimibe but continues to have an LDL-cholesterol level above goal. Adding a PCSK9 inhibitor such as evolocumab or alirocumab is the best next step.

Key learning point: For patients intolerant of statin therapy who are already taking ezetimibe but continue to have an LDL-cholesterol level above goal, cardiovascular risk can best be reduced by initiating a proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 (PCSK9) inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl can be used to reduce cardiovascular risk in patients with persistently elevated triglycerides >135 mg/dL and LDL-cholesterol <100 mg/dL. This patient does not meet these criteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Simvastatin is a lipophilic statin and more likely to cause adverse muscle effects than two of the statins this patient has already tried (pravastatin and rosuvastatin). Therefore, starting simvastatin is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Although some think that coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) depletion may play a role in statin myopathy, there is little published evidence showing a benefit for CoQ10 supplementation in the treatment or prevention of statin myalgias.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrates lower triglyceride levels, raise HDL-cholesterol levels, and lower LDL-cholesterol levels. However, data have shown that fenofibrate has no real role in secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. It has a small role in severe hypertriglyceridemia.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents for a well visit. She has no history of hospitalizations or surgeries, and her only oral medication is a multivitamin. She was taking oral isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne until about 6 months ago but now uses only topical medications. Her family history is significant for obesity in both parents, and her father had a heart attack at age 50.
When asked about her diet and exercise habits, the patient reports that she enjoys fast food and soda but has made positive changes during the past year; she has been eating better and exercising regularly — and has lost 7 kg of body weight as a result. She does not smoke.
On examination, her BMI is at the 97th percentile for age. Her systolic and diastolic blood pressure is below the 95th percentile corrected for age and height. A head and neck examination is normal. Her lungs are clear, and she has a regular heart rhythm without murmurs. Her abdomen is obese without tenderness or organomegaly. She has no edema or rashes.
A fasting lipid profile is obtained on two occasions, 4 weeks apart, with the following average results:



Patient value


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
271


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
192


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
53


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
160


The patient’s thyroid-stimulating hormone level is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Encourage continued lifestyle modification and repeat the lipid panel in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although further lifestyle modification should be encouraged (and referral to a nutritionist may help with this), the most appropriate next step for this patient is to start a cholesterol-lowering medication. Continued observation is not indicated when the LDL level is this high.

B) INCORRECT:

Initial management of hyperlipidemia always includes lifestyle modification — increased physical activity; a diet with less saturated fat, less cholesterol, and more fiber; and, in patients with obesity, weight loss. Although further lifestyle modification should be encouraged (and referral to a nutritionist may help with this), the most appropriate next step for this patient is to start a cholesterol-lowering medication.

C) INCORRECT:

Metformin is used to treat type 2 diabetes and may help with insulin resistance and impaired fasting glucose. Although this patient's obesity and elevated triglyceride level suggest the possibility of metabolic syndrome, she does not currently meet the criteria: her HDL-cholesterol level and blood pressure are normal, and her glucose level is not known to be impaired. There is no indication for metformin in an adolescent with an unknown fasting glucose level and an unclear metabolic syndrome status.

D) INCORRECT:

Treatment for hypertriglyceridemia, with an agent such as fenofibrate, is not typically indicated unless the triglyceride level is >500 mg/dL. This patient’s fasting triglyceride level (160 mg/dL) is well below that threshold. Of note, whether a child is fasting at the time of a lipid panel affects the triglyceride levels.

E) CORRECT:

The American Academy of Pediatrics, the American Heart Association, and the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute all recommend pediatric screening for hyperlipidemia. The general consensus is to perform universal screening with either a fasting or nonfasting lipid profile in all children between the ages of 9 and 11 — and then again between the ages of 17 and 21. Screening is recommended between the ages of 12 and 16 only for children who have risk factors for heart disease.

This patient was eligible for universal screening given her age, but she also had multiple risk factors for hyperlipidemia, including obesity and a family history of early coronary artery disease. On two separate screenings, her LDL-cholesterol level averaged >190 mg/dL, warranting intervention.

Initial management of hyperlipidemia always includes lifestyle modification — increased physical activity; a diet with less saturated fat, less cholesterol, and more fiber; and, in patients with obesity, weight loss. It is also important to rule out other modifiable causes of the hyperlipidemia, such as hypothyroidism and medication use. In this particular case, the patient’s thyroid-stimulating hormone level is normal, and she is not taking any medications known to cause hyperlipidemia. Although isotretinoin is known to increase LDL-cholesterol and triglyceride levels, the increases are usually transient, and the patient has not been on this medication for the past 6 months. Although further lifestyle modification should be encouraged (and referral to a nutritionist may help with this), the most appropriate next step for this patient is to start a cholesterol-lowering medication.

Statin therapy is indicated in children and adolescents who have an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL and in those who have an LDL-cholesterol level between 130 and 189 mg/dL with risk factors for cardiovascular disease. This patient has an LDL-cholesterol level >190 mg/dL, warranting treatment. Continued observation is not indicated when the LDL level is this high. Several statins — including atorvastatin, rosuvastatin, and simvastatin — are approved for use in children. Therapy should begin with the lowest possible dose, once daily in the evening, and be titrated upward as needed to a target LDL-cholesterol level of ≤130 mg/dL.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in care for an adolescent whose LDL cholesterol level is ≥190 mg/dL after at least 6 months of lifestyle modification with associated weight loss is to start cholesterol-lowering medication.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents for follow-up. He has a history of primary hypertension that was not responsive to 6 months of lifestyle interventions but has been responsive to losartan.
He has no family history of early heart disease. He reports no illicit drug use, smoking, or sexual activity. His family has implemented a heart-healthy diet for the past year, and he exercises four times per week.
On physical examination, he is in no clear distress. He has a heart rate of 75 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 118/74 mm Hg, a height of 165 cm (13th percentile), a weight of 77 kg (88th percentile), and a BMI at the 98th percentile.
He has clear lung fields, a regular heart rate and rhythm without abdominal or carotid bruit, and 2+ bilateral radial and femoral pulses. His abdomen is soft and nondistended without hepatomegaly, and he has no peripheral edema. The rest of his examination is unremarkable.
A comprehensive metabolic panel shows normal findings. The rest of his latest laboratory results are shown below:



Patient value
Reference range


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
5.5
4.5–5.6


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
209
<170


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
156
<110


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
32
>35


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
280
24–145


Glucose (mg/dL)
95
70–105


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
1.2
0.5–4.0


In addition to close follow-up, what is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrates, such as gemfibrozil, are PPAR-alpha (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha) agonists that upregulate lipoprotein lipase and apolipoprotein C-III, both of which degrade very-low-density-lipoprotein cholesterol and triglycerides. Use of a fibrate, whose main effect is in lowering triglyceride levels, may be considered in children who have an average fasting triglyceride level ≥500 mg/dL or any single triglyceride measurement ≥1000 mg/dL. A fibrate is not appropriate first-line therapy for hyperlipidemia in this patient but may be considered if his non-HDL-cholesterol level does not respond to intensification of statin therapy.

Niacin and fibrates have been useful to treat adults who have combined dyslipidemias, but there is limited published experience with these agents in children. Thus, the use of niacin, fibrates, and cholesterol-absorption inhibitors in children should be instituted only in consultation with a lipid specialist

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient should continue his efforts at comprehensive lifestyle-based diet and exercise interventions, that would not be sufficient alone.

C) CORRECT:

Recommendations for statin therapy in children ≥10 years of age depend on the patient’s fasting LDL-cholesterol level and risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD). Once sources of secondary dyslipidemia have been ruled out, statin therapy is recommended for the following three groups:

• Those with LDL cholesterol ≥190 mg/dL
• Those with LDL cholesterol 160–189 mg/dL, plus one of the following: family history of premature CVD, ≥1 major risk factor for CVD, or ≥2 minor risk factors for CVD
• Those with LDL cholesterol 130–159 mg/dL plus either ≥2 major risk factors for CVD or 1 major and 2 minor risk factors for CVD

Major risk factors include:

• Hypertension treated with medication
• BMI at ≥97th percentile
• Diabetes mellitus
• History of heart transplant
• Kawasaki disease with persistent coronary aneurysm
• Chronic or end-stage kidney disease or history of kidney transplant
• Tobacco use

Minor risk factors include:

• Hypertension not treated with medication
• BMI ≥95th percentile and <97th percentile
• HDL cholesterol <40 mg/dL
• Kawasaki disease with regressed coronary aneurysm
• HIV infection
• Nephrotic syndrome
• Chronic inflammatory disease (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis)

This patient has a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level, thus ruling out hypothyroidism as a potential cause of his dyslipidemia. He has a fasting LDL cholesterol level of 156 mg/dL with two major risk factors for CVD (medication-treated hypertension and BMI ≥97th percentile) and one minor risk factor (HDL cholesterol <40 mg/dL) and is therefore a candidate for statin therapy (e.g., with atorvastatin).

Although this patient should continue his efforts at comprehensive lifestyle-based diet and exercise interventions, that would not be sufficient alone.

Statin therapy should begin with the lowest available dose given once daily. If the LDL-cholesterol target level of ≤130 mg/dL is not achieved with at least 3 months of adherent use, then the statin dose may be increased. The risks and benefits of dose escalation have been explored in several clinical trials of statins in children, and no additional safety issues have been identified.

Niacin and fibrates have been useful to treat adults who have combined dyslipidemias, but there is limited published experience with these agents in children. Thus, the use of niacin, fibrates, and cholesterol-absorption inhibitors in children should be instituted only in consultation with a lipid specialist.

Of note, children younger than 10 years of age should not be treated with a statin unless they have a severe primary hyperlipidemia or a high-risk condition that is associated with serious medical morbidity (LDL cholesterol level ≥400 mg/dL, triglyceride level ≥500 mg/dL, or postcardiac transplantation), in which case they should be cared for by a lipid specialist. This recommendation is based on a concern that statins may disrupt normal lipid metabolism needed for development.

Key learning point: Statin therapy is recommended for children and adolescents who have an LDL cholesterol level of 130–159 mg/dL if they also have either ≥2 major risk factors for cardiovascular disease or 1 major and 2 minor risk factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Bile-acid sequestrants, such as cholestyramine, bind intestinal bile acids and interrupt enterohepatic recirculation, which results in a larger amount of cholesterol being converted into bile acids and upregulation of LDL receptors. Studies in children and adolescents have shown a small resulting reduction in total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol levels, sometimes with a modest elevation in triglyceride levels. Bile-acid sequestrants commonly have gastrointestinal side effects that significantly affect adherence. They are not the most appropriate first-line therapy in this patient and would only be considered for him if statin therapy were to fail.

E) INCORRECT:

In adolescents with severe obesity and insulin resistance, the addition of metformin to a comprehensive lifestyle-based weight-loss program has been shown to improve fasting insulin levels and significantly reduce body weight and BMI. However, this patient, with his normal fasting glucose and glycated hemoglobin levels, is not exhibiting insulin resistance.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because they are worried about her weight. They have repeatedly tried to make her lose weight over the past year by encouraging her to exercise and eat healthy without any success. She feels well, and her medical history is unremarkable. Her father has hypercholesterolemia and coronary artery disease and her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She is 164 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 83 kg (183 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 127/81 mm Hg. She is at the > 90th percentile for waist circumference. Physical examination shows multiple yellow-pink papules around her elbows and on the back of her thighs. Serum studies show:


Fasting glucose
102 mg/dL


Total cholesterol
347 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
100 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
45 mg/dL


Triglycerides
1012 mg/dL


HbA1c
5.8%


Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is the drug of choice for children and adolescents with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Although this patient has prediabetes (HbA1c 5.8%, fasting glucose 100–125 mg/dL), pharmacotherapy for diabetes is not indicated at this point. This patient requires pharmacotherapy for severe hypertriglyceridemia, for which metformin is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, a second-line treatment for children and adolescents with hypercholesterolemia, also slightly lowers serum triglyceride levels. However, it is not the treatment of choice for a patient with severe hypertriglyceridemia.

C) CORRECT:

While management of children and adolescents with hypertriglyceridemia mainly focuses on lifestyle modification (i.e., promoting a healthy diet, physical activity, and weight loss), pharmacotherapy to reduce the risk of acute pancreatitis should be initiated in patients with triglyceride serum levels >1000 mg/dL and can be considered for patients with serum levels of 400–1000 mg/dL. Fibrates, such as fenofibrate, are the most effective drug for lowering triglyceride serum levels and therefore are the treatment of choice.

Causes of dyslipidemia in children and adolescents include an unhealthy diet (e.g., high in saturated fats), an underlying condition (e.g., obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus), and genetic defects. This patient's presentation with severe hypertriglyceridemia and a family history of dyslipidemia suggests a genetic disorder (e.g., familial hypertriglyceridemia). While hypertriglyceridemia itself is not a strong risk factor for cardiovascular disease, affected patients commonly have other cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., diabetes mellitus, obesity).
Image Description:

A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.

Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.

D) INCORRECT:

Orlistat can be used for weight loss in obese patients and has a favorable effect on serum lipid values. Although this patient might benefit from orlistat, her severely elevated serum triglyceride levels put her at increased risk for acute pancreatitis, so another pharmacotherapy is more appropriate at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Statins (e.g., atorvastatin), the first-line pharmacological treatment for children and adolescents with hypercholesterolemia, are also moderately effective in lowering serum triglyceride levels. However, statins are not the treatment of choice for a patient with severe hypertriglyceridemia.
questions.hint: This obese adolescent presents with features of insulin resistance (impaired fasting glucose) and severe hypertriglyceridemia (> 1000 mg/dL) with eruptive xanthomas. She is at risk for acute triglyceride-induced pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. He has a history of stable angina, gout, and hypertension. His medications include lisinopril and aspirin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks 5–6 beers on the weekends. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a total cholesterol of 276 mg/dL with an elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) concentration and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) concentration. In addition to dietary and lifestyle modifications, administration of which of the following agents is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a lipid-lowering agent that is synthesized from tryptophan. It decreases hepatic very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis, inhibits the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, increases HDL levels, and, to a lesser degree, reduces triglyceride and LDL synthesis. Niacin is not, however, first-line monotherapy in patients with hyperlipidemia. Furthermore, it is not recommended in patients with gout because of the associated risk of hyperuricemia.

B) CORRECT:

Statins are first-line treatment for hyperlipidemia. Statins inhibit the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, thereby decreasing cholesterol synthesis in the liver. Statins are the most effective drug for reducing LDL levels, and they also increase HDL and lower triglyceride levels. Common side effects of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors include elevated LFTs and myalgias (especially when used with fibrates).

Key learning point: Statins are the first-line pharmacologic therapy for hyperlipidemia due to their effectiveness in lowering LDL cholesterol and reducing cardiovascular risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrates (e.g., bezafibrate, fenofibrate) activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α). The activation of PPAR-α increases lipoprotein lipase production, fatty acid uptake and oxidation, as well as HDL synthesis. Fibrates effectively decrease triglyceride levels and increase HDL levels, and only have a mild effect on LDL levels. Therefore, fibrates are not appropriate as monotherapy for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor, decreases LDL levels by inhibiting cholesterol absorption at the brush borders of the small intestine. However, ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent and is reserved for patients who do not tolerate first-line therapy. Side effects of ezetimibe include diarrhea and increased LFTs.

E) INCORRECT:

Cholestyramine, a bile acid resin, lowers plasma LDL levels by binding to bile acid, thereby preventing bile acid reabsorption in the gastrointestinal tract and increasing intestinal LDL losses. Bile acid resins are not first-line therapy for hyperlipidemia because they have gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., diarrhea) and only lower LDL levels minimally.
questions.hint: This patient has hyperlipidemia and a history that suggests coronary artery disease (stable angina).

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with no known medical history is hospitalized and treated for an acute coronary syndrome. On admission, she is noted to have obesity and nodularity of her Achilles tendons. Her father died suddenly in his early fifties. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


LDL cholesterol

223 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
46 mg/dL


Total cholesterol

303 mg/dL


Triglycerides
171 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
5.4 μU/mL


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertriglyceridemia is associated with cardiovascular disease but does not result in xanthomas or a severely elevated LDL-cholesterol level.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is characterized by an elevated serum triglyceride level but low levels of HDL and LDL cholesterol.

C) INCORRECT:

Combined hyperlipidemia (manifest by hypercholesterolemia and hypertriglyceridemia) is not associated with a markedly elevated serum LDL-cholesterol level or with xanthomas.

D) CORRECT:

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by markedly elevated levels of serum LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol. The diagnosis of heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia can be confirmed by genetic testing but is frequently made clinically in patients with a total cholesterol level ranging from 350 to 550 mg/dL or an LDL-cholesterol level ranging from 200 to 400 mg/dL. Tendinous xanthomas, as evident on this patient’s Achilles tendons, are pathognomonic for the diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia and are not found in secondary causes of hypercholesterolemia.

Key learning point: Tendinous xanthomas are pathognomonic for the diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism, a frequent cause of hyperlipidemia typically associated with a high serum LDL cholesterol levels, is not associated with xanthomas.
questions.hint: This condition often remains undiagnosed until an acute coronary syndrome or another cardiovascular event occurs and a family history of premature cardiovascular disease in first-degree relatives is common.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of seizures controlled with levetiracetam. She has needed glasses for the past 13 years. Her father died of pancreatic cancer. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the face is shown. This patient is most likely at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas are tumors that are particularly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, which often manifests initially with impaired eyesight and might also present with seizures. Although disease onset may not occur until adulthood, the lesions on the eyelids of this patient do not resemble the characteristic skin lesions found in neurofibromatosis type 1 (café au lait spots, Lisch nodules).
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastric cancer is often asymptomatic until advanced disease stages present with abdominal pain, hematemesis, or gastric outlet obstruction. A further symptom that may occur is malignant acanthosis nigricans, which presents with verrucous skin lesions predominantly on the axillae, groin, or neck. While gastric cancer cannot be ruled out conclusively in an asymptomatic patient without further workup, the xanthelasmas seen in this patient suggest a diagnosis that increases her risk for a different condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Early-onset glaucoma is a condition that is often associated with congenital diseases such as Sturge-Weber syndrome. While patients may present with seizures and initially only require glasses to correct refractive errors associated with glaucoma, the diagnosis is usually established in childhood. This patient's skin lesions also do not resemble the characteristic port-wine stain seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with xanthelasmas, small nodular lipid deposits that manifest bilaterally on the upper eyelids. Xanthelasmas are a symptom of underlying lipid disorders (e.g., familial hypercholesterolemia, obesity), which increase the risk for atherosclerosis and associated cardiovascular diseases such as coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and stroke. The next best step in management would be to identify the underlying cause of this patient's lipid disorder via laboratory analysis of serum lipid levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor associated with tuberous sclerosis. While the condition can manifest with seizures and skin lesions that affect the face (adenoma sebaceum), it is not associated with xanthelasmas and is unlikely in the absence of further characteristic symptoms (e.g., intellectual disability, brain tumors, ash-leaf spots).
questions.hint: This patient has bilateral xanthelasma (sharply demarcated, yellow plaques) on the nasal aspect of her eyelids.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Early detection and treatment of hyperlipidemia is crucial to prevent ASCVD events like stroke or myocardial infarction. The guidelines for hyperlipidemia screening differ slightly among various expert groups. The current consensus is to screen all individuals aged 20–75 years using a fasting or nonfasting serum lipid profile test every 4–6 years in patients without additional ASCVD risk factors and at more frequent intervals in those with additional ASCVD risk factors.

See “Screening recommendations for men by age” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia and gonorrhea are the most common causes of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID is most often asymptomatic, it can result in severe complications, including infertility and ectopic pregnancy. Therefore, both the USPSTF and CDC recommend annual screening with a nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active women < 25 years and women ≥ 25 years with certain risk factors (e.g., new or multiple sex partners, a sex partner with an STI). The CDC also recommends annual screening for both sexually active HIV-positive men and men who have sex with men because of the higher incidence of gonorrhea and chlamydia infections in these populations. Routine chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is not currently recommended for sexually active, HIV-negative men in monogamous, heterosexual relationships, such as this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The AHA and other expert groups do recommend screening for a certain disease in this patient's age group.

D) INCORRECT:

The guidelines for prostate cancer screening differ slightly among various expert groups but the USPSTF recommends screening men aged 55–69 years with a life expectancy of at least 10 years after informing the patient of the benefits as well as risks of prostate cancer screening (e.g., relatively high false-positive rate, additional unnecessary procedures), i.e., by employing a shared decision-making strategy. Prostate cancer screening is most commonly performed using a serum prostate-specific antigen test every 2 years. Screening can be initiated earlier at 40 years for patients with a first-degree relative who developed early-onset prostate cancer (i.e., before 65 years). This 42-year-old patient with a second-degree relative who developed prostate cancer at the age of 73 years does not require prostate cancer screening at this visit.

E) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient evidence to recommend routine screening for osteoporosis in men, but screening can be considered in men with strong risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use; androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer) and in men ≥ 70 years of age. In this 42-year old man without such risk factors, screening for osteoporosis is not recommended.
questions.hint: Screening for this disorder is recommended by the American Heart Association and various other expert groups for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD).

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the onset of progressively worsening upper abdominal pain and 4 episodes of vomiting. His father has a lipid disorder. Physical examination shows tenderness and guarding in the epigastrium. Bowel sounds are decreased. His serum amylase is 400 U/L. Symptomatic treatment and therapy with fenofibrate are initiated. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salt and pepper skull refers to a characteristic pattern of tiny, radiolucent areas within the calvaria, which classically occurs in the setting of hyperparathyroidism. High calcium levels can lead to premature activation of pancreatic enzymes and therefore pancreatitis. However, as this patient has no mentioned history of hypercalcemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, polyuria, constipation, neuropsychiatric disturbances), salt and pepper skull would be unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Eruptive xanthomas occur due to lipid deposition in the dermis and are associated with hypertriglyceridemia. This patient's family history of a lipid disorder supports familial hypertriglyceridemia as the underlying cause of his pancreatitis. Treatment generally focuses on dietary restrictions and initiation of fibric acid derivatives, such as fenofibrate.
Image Description:

A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.

Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum ACTH levels can be found in patients with prolonged steroid use, which can lead to exogenous hypercortisolism. Although steroid use is associated with the development of pancreatitis, this patient does not exhibit additional features linked to chronic steroid intake (e.g., truncal obesity, striae, moon facies). In addition, decreased serum ACTH levels due to steroid use would be treated by slowly tapering steroids, not by prescribing fenofibrate.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IgG4 levels occur in the setting of autoimmune pancreatitis, which is associated with other autoimmune disorders such as retroperitoneal fibrosis, Riedel thyroiditis, and non-infectious aortitis. This patient does not have a personal or family history of any of these conditions. Also, autoimmune pancreatitis would be treated with steroids, not fenofibrate.

E) INCORRECT:

Bilateral parotid gland enlargement is the hallmark of mumps, of which acute pancreatitis is a rare complication. This patient, however, has not had any classic prodromal findings of mumps, e.g., low-grade fever or malaise. Moreover, fenofibrate would be of no use in mumps-associated pancreatitis, as this complication typically resolves with symptomatic therapy alone.
questions.hint: These findings of worsening epigastric pain with tenderness and guarding in the setting of elevated amylase levels are highly indicative of pancreatitis. The fact that this patient was prescribed fenofibrate indicates that severe hypertriglyceridemia was diagnosed as the underlying cause of his pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a 20-year history of daily tobacco use has borderline LDL and low HDL. She regularly exercises and denies diabetes. Which intervention best lowers her coronary heart disease risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-intensity statins are indicated for patients with significantly elevated LDL cholesterol, established cardiovascular disease, or high 10-year coronary event risk. This patient has borderline LDL levels and is relatively young, making tobacco cessation a more impactful intervention for reducing coronary heart disease risk.

B) INCORRECT:

A low-fat diet can reduce LDL levels by decreasing saturated fat intake. However, the patient's most significant modifiable risk factor is tobacco use. Dietary changes offer modest improvements compared to the substantial impact of tobacco cessation on coronary heart disease risk.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic tobacco use is a significant modifiable risk factor for coronary heart disease. It adversely affects lipid metabolism by reducing high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels and promoting oxidative modification of low-density lipoprotein (LDL). These changes contribute to endothelial dysfunction and inflammation, increasing coronary plaque formation. Eliminating tobacco use improves endothelial function and lipid profiles, reducing coronary heart disease risk. Tobacco cessation is a primary prevention strategy for cardiovascular disease.

Key learning point: Smoking is a major preventable cause of dyslipidemia and coronary heart disease in women, impacting lipid levels and significantly increasing cardiovascular risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Daily low-dose aspirin reduces thrombotic events in high-risk individuals or those with established cardiovascular disease. In low-risk individuals, the bleeding risk often outweighs benefits. This patient, despite tobacco use, does not meet criteria for aspirin use based on current guidelines.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic for an annual health maintenance examination. He has a history of stable angina, gout, and hypertension. His medications are lisinopril and aspirin. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. He drinks 5–6 beers on weekends. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a total cholesterol of 7.1 mmol/L (3.5–5.2), a low-density lipoprotein level (LDL) of 4.6 mmol/L, and a high-density lipoprotein level (HDL) of 0.9 mmol/L (>1.0).

questions.text:
You are caring for a 43-year-old woman with no known medical history who is hospitalized and treated for an acute coronary syndrome. On admission, you note that she has obesity and nodularity of her Achilles tendons. Her father died suddenly in his early fifties. Laboratory findings are as follows:


Cholesterol, LDL, blood

5.8 mmol/L (see the LDL Analysis table below)


Cholesterol, HDL, blood
1.2 mmol/L (>1.3)


Cholesterol, total, blood

7.8 mmol/L (3.5–5.2)

A cluster of well-defined papules 2–5 mm in size can be seen. Most papules have a yellow apex and an erythematous border.

Eruptive xanthomas are cutaneous lipid deposits typically seen in patients with type I hyperlipidemia (hyperchylomicronemia). They usually occur on the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the body.

D) INCORRECT:

Bilateral parotid gland enlargement is the hallmark of mumps, of which acute pancreatitis is a rare complication. This patient, however, has not had any classic prodromal findings of mumps, e.g., low-grade fever or malaise. Moreover, fenofibrate would be of no use in mumps-associated pancreatitis, as this complication typically resolves with symptomatic therapy alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IgG4 levels occur in the setting of autoimmune pancreatitis, which is associated with other autoimmune disorders such as retroperitoneal fibrosis, Riedel thyroiditis, and non-infectious aortitis. This patient does not have a personal or family history of any of these conditions. Also, autoimmune pancreatitis would be treated with steroids, not fenofibrate.
questions.hint: These findings of worsening epigastric pain with tenderness and guarding in the setting of elevated amylase levels are highly indicative of pancreatitis. The fact that this patient was prescribed fenofibrate indicates that severe hypertriglyceridemia was diagnosed as the underlying cause of his pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman establishes care at a new primary care clinic. She reports increasing fatigue and constipation over the past six months, which she attributes to stress. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Her BMI is 24 kg/m². Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable except for dry skin. Routine screening laboratory tests show a total cholesterol of 285 mg/dL, LDL of 198 mg/dL, HDL of 42 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 225 mg/dL. Her fasting glucose is 92 mg/dL. In addition to counseling on diet and exercise, which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to evaluate for an underlying cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is a common cause of secondary dyslipidemia, typically characterized by high triglycerides and low HDL. Although hemoglobin A1c is used to diagnose diabetes, this patient's normal fasting glucose of 92 mg/dL makes diabetes an unlikely underlying cause for her presentation. Her other symptoms are not specific for diabetes.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of fatigue, constipation, and dry skin, combined with new-onset mixed hyperlipidemia, is highly suggestive of hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism is a common secondary cause of dyslipidemia, primarily due to decreased clearance of LDL cholesterol from a reduction in LDL receptor activity. It can also impair triglyceride clearance. Measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is the most sensitive and specific screening test for primary hypothyroidism. Identifying and treating an underlying thyroid disorder is crucial because it can significantly improve or even normalize the lipid profile, potentially obviating the need for statin therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring ALT is part of a liver function panel, which is important to obtain before initiating statin therapy. Certain liver diseases, such as cholestasis, can also cause hypercholesterolemia. However, this patient has no signs or symptoms of liver disease, and an ALT level itself is not the primary test to diagnose the most likely underlying endocrine cause of her dyslipidemia.

D) INCORRECT:

A 24-hour urinary free cortisol test is used to screen for Cushing syndrome, which can cause secondary dyslipidemia. However, this patient does not exhibit the characteristic signs of hypercortisolism, such as central obesity, facial plethora, purple striae, or hypertension. Her clinical presentation makes this diagnosis unlikely, making this specialized test inappropriate as an initial step.

E) INCORRECT:

A urinalysis can screen for proteinuria, which would suggest nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a known secondary cause of hyperlipidemia due to increased hepatic lipoprotein synthesis. However, this patient does not have any clinical signs of nephrotic syndrome, such as edema or hypertension, making this diagnosis less likely than other causes for her specific symptoms.
questions.hint: Always consider secondary causes of dyslipidemia, especially when a patient presents with new-onset lipid abnormalities accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fatigue, constipation, and dry skin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. He quit smoking 10 years ago, and his father had a myocardial infarction at age 58. His blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg, and his BMI is 28 kg/m². A fasting lipid panel shows total cholesterol of 235 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol of 42 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 170 mg/dL. His calculated LDL cholesterol is 159 mg/dL. His 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk is calculated to be 12%. In addition to lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate is a fibrate medication primarily used to lower high triglyceride levels. It might seem plausible because this patient's triglycerides are borderline elevated. However, fibrates are generally reserved for severe hypertriglyceridemia (e.g., > 500 mg/dL) to reduce the risk of pancreatitis and are not the initial choice for ASCVD risk reduction, especially when the primary target is lowering LDL cholesterol.

B) INCORRECT:

Niacin can lower LDL cholesterol and triglycerides while raising HDL cholesterol. However, due to a significant side effect profile (e.g., flushing, hyperglycemia) and clinical trials failing to show a reduction in cardiovascular events when added to statin therapy, niacin is no longer recommended as a primary or secondary agent for routine lipid management.

C) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol by inhibiting its absorption in the small intestine. Although effective, it is not considered a first-line agent for primary prevention. It is typically recommended as an add-on therapy for patients who are on a maximally tolerated statin but have not reached their LDL goal or as an alternative for patients who are intolerant to statins.

D) INCORRECT:

Colesevelam is a bile acid sequestrant that lowers LDL cholesterol. However, its LDL-lowering effect is less potent than that of statins, and it can cause an increase in triglyceride levels, which would be undesirable in this patient. It is considered a second- or third-line agent and is not appropriate as initial therapy for primary prevention.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's 10-year ASCVD risk is 12%, placing him in the intermediate-risk category (7.5% to < 20%). For primary prevention in this group, guidelines recommend initiating a moderate-intensity statin in addition to lifestyle modifications. Statins (3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase inhibitors) are the first-line therapy because they have been extensively proven to reduce the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events by lowering LDL cholesterol. Atorvastatin is a commonly prescribed statin that can be dosed to provide moderate-intensity (10–20 mg) or high-intensity (40–80 mg) therapy. The presence of risk-enhancing factors, such as his family history of premature ASCVD, further strengthens the indication for statin therapy.
questions.hint: According to the 2018 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines, patients aged 40–75 without diabetes and with an LDL cholesterol level of 70–189 mg/dL should have their 10-year ASCVD risk calculated to guide therapy. This patient falls into the intermediate-risk category.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes for a health maintenance examination. He has a history of type 2 diabetes diagnosed two years ago but has not seen a physician since and takes no medications. He reports increased thirst and frequent urination over the past several months. He has a family history of heart disease. His BMI is 31 kg/m². His vital signs are normal. Fasting laboratory studies show a glucose of 310 mg/dL, hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) of 11.2%, total cholesterol of 280 mg/dL, HDL of 28 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 750 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention to manage this patient's hypertriglyceridemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A high-intensity statin is indicated for this patient to reduce his risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease due to his age and diagnosis of diabetes. Although statins have a modest triglyceride-lowering effect, they are not the primary therapy for severe hypertriglyceridemia. The most critical initial step for managing the triglycerides is to address the profound hyperglycemia that is driving the dyslipidemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Niacin can lower triglycerides, but its use is limited by significant side effects and a lack of proven cardiovascular benefit when added to a statin. More importantly, a common side effect of niacin is hyperglycemia, which would be detrimental to this patient with an already dangerously high HbA1c and fasting glucose.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's severe hypertriglyceridemia is most likely secondary to his poorly controlled type 2 diabetes. Insulin resistance leads to increased hepatic VLDL production and decreased activity of lipoprotein lipase, an enzyme crucial for clearing triglycerides from the circulation. Therefore, the most appropriate initial intervention is to address the underlying cause by improving glycemic control. Metformin is the first-line pharmacologic agent for type 2 diabetes, and when combined with lifestyle modifications such as diet, exercise, and weight loss, it significantly improves insulin sensitivity. This, in turn, substantially lowers triglyceride levels, often without the need for additional lipid-lowering agents.

D) INCORRECT:

Prescription omega-3 fatty acids are effective at lowering triglyceride levels. However, they are typically used as an adjunct to statin therapy for patients with persistent hypertriglyceridemia. They are not the first-line intervention when elevated triglycerides are a direct consequence of another untreated condition, such as the severe hyperglycemia seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate is a potent triglyceride-lowering agent used to reduce the risk of pancreatitis in patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia (typically > 500 mg/dL). However, this patient's condition is secondary to uncontrolled diabetes. The primary step is to treat the underlying cause. Fibrate therapy would be considered if triglyceride levels remain severely elevated despite adequate glycemic control.
questions.hint: In patients with poorly controlled diabetes, severe hypertriglyceridemia is often a secondary phenomenon.

questions.text: A 13-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. A venous blood sample obtained for routine screening tests is milky. After refrigeration, a creamy supernatant layer appears on top of the sample. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the apolipoprotein C-II gene (APOC2) on chromosome 19. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with familial hyperchylomicronemia can develop eruptive xanthomas but do not typically develop tendinous xanthomas. The formation of tendinous xanthomas is associated with familial hypercholesterolemia (which is caused by defects in LDL receptors or apolipoprotein B-100).

B) CORRECT:

Patients with familial hyperchylomicronemia (type I dyslipidemia) have an increased risk of developing recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. These patients typically have serum triglyceride concentrations > 880 mg/dL; the breakdown of these triglycerides by pancreatic lipases creates free fatty acids that directly injure the pancreas and cause an autoinflammatory response. Additional manifestations of familial hyperchylomicronemia that can develop during childhood include eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis, and hepatosplenomegaly (due to chylomicron accumulation).

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with familial hyperchylomicronemia do not develop early atherosclerosis and thus do not have an increased risk of having a myocardial infarction (MI) compared to the general population. Familial dyslipidemias that are associated with early atherosclerosis include familial hypercholesterolemia (which is caused by defects in LDL receptors or apolipoprotein B-100) and familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (which is caused by defects in apolipoprotein E).

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with familial hyperchylomicronemia do not have severely increased serum LDL concentrations and thus do not have an increased risk of developing corneal arci compared to the general population. The formation of corneal arci is associated with familial hypercholesterolemia (which is caused by defects in LDL receptors or apolipoprotein B-100). Familial hyperchylomicronemia is associated with lipemia retinalis, a discoloration of the retinal vessels and/or fundus due to light scattering from increased concentrations of chylomicrons.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of the left eye

A white opacity, caused by lipid deposition, lines the lower and slightly also the upper periphery of the cornea while being clearly separated from the limbus by clear cornea.

This is the typical appearance of an arcus senilis. In the early stages, it is usually seen in the inferior cornea. It may extend to a full circle in more advanced stages. If present in young individuals blood lipid levels should be examined.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with familial hyperchylomicronemia do not develop early atherosclerosis and thus do not have an increased risk of developing cholesterol embolization syndrome compared to the general population. Familial dyslipidemias that are associated with early atherosclerosis include familial hypercholesterolemia (which is caused by defects in LDL receptors or apolipoprotein B-100) and familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (which is caused by defects in apolipoprotein E).

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with familial hyperchylomicronemia do not develop early atherosclerosis and thus do not have an increased risk of having a cerebrovascular accident compared to the general population. Familial dyslipidemias that are associated with early atherosclerosis include familial hypercholesterolemia (which is caused by defects in LDL receptors or apolipoprotein B-100) and familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (which is caused by defects in apolipoprotein E).
questions.hint: This patient has familial hyperchylomicronemia (type I dyslipidemia), an autosomal recessive condition caused by a deficiency of apolipoprotein C-II or lipoprotein lipase. This condition causes increased serum concentrations of chylomicrons, triglycerides, and cholesterol, which results in milky coloration of the serum as seen in this patient.
